issue.title: VipsOperation: class "heifsave_buffer" not found
issue.body:
## Bug report

**Describe the bug**
Similar to the threads indicated below. I'm receiving `VipsOperation: class "heifsave_buffer" not found` on Digital Ocean App Platform when trying to run Sharp on via Strapi CMS. Specifcally when converting to `Avif` and `WebP`.

I'm not sure if this is a host issue, or if there is something I can change within the Dockerfile for it to work.

- https://github.com/libvips/libvips/discussions/2340
- https://github.com/lovell/sharp/issues/2783

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Use Dockerfile

```
# Build
FROM node:18-alpine as build

ARG DATABASE_URL

ENV NODE_ENV=production
ENV DATABASE_URL=${DATABASE_URL}

WORKDIR /opt/
COPY package*.json ./
RUN apk add --no-cache build-base gcc autoconf automake zlib-dev libpng-dev vips-dev > /dev/null 2>&1
RUN npm install --omit=dev
ENV PATH /opt/node_modules/.bin:$PATH
WORKDIR /opt/app
COPY . .

RUN npm run build

# Run
FROM node:18-alpine as production
RUN apk add --no-cache vips-dev
ENV NODE_ENV=production

WORKDIR /opt/
COPY --from=build /opt/node_modules ./node_modules
WORKDIR /opt/app
COPY --from=build /opt/app ./
ENV PATH /opt/node_modules/.bin:$PATH

RUN chown -R node:node /opt/app
USER node
EXPOSE 3000
CMD ["npm", "run", "start"]
```

2. See error

```
error: VipsOperation: class "heifsave_buffer" not found
Error: VipsOperation: class "heifsave_buffer" not found
node:events:495
throw er; // Unhandled 'error' event
```

**Environment**
(please complete the following information)
 - OS: Node 18 Alpine

comment.body: `RUN apk add --no-cache build-base gcc autoconf automake zlib-dev libpng-dev vips-dev libheif-dev > /dev/null 2>&1  # Add libheif-dev for HEIF support`

issue.title: VipsOperation: class "heifsave_buffer" not found
issue.body:
## Bug report

**Describe the bug**
Similar to the threads indicated below. I'm receiving `VipsOperation: class "heifsave_buffer" not found` on Digital Ocean App Platform when trying to run Sharp on via Strapi CMS. Specifcally when converting to `Avif` and `WebP`.

I'm not sure if this is a host issue, or if there is something I can change within the Dockerfile for it to work.

- https://github.com/libvips/libvips/discussions/2340
- https://github.com/lovell/sharp/issues/2783

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Use Dockerfile

```
# Build
FROM node:18-alpine as build

ARG DATABASE_URL

ENV NODE_ENV=production
ENV DATABASE_URL=${DATABASE_URL}

WORKDIR /opt/
COPY package*.json ./
RUN apk add --no-cache build-base gcc autoconf automake zlib-dev libpng-dev vips-dev > /dev/null 2>&1
RUN npm install --omit=dev
ENV PATH /opt/node_modules/.bin:$PATH
WORKDIR /opt/app
COPY . .

RUN npm run build

# Run
FROM node:18-alpine as production
RUN apk add --no-cache vips-dev
ENV NODE_ENV=production

WORKDIR /opt/
COPY --from=build /opt/node_modules ./node_modules
WORKDIR /opt/app
COPY --from=build /opt/app ./
ENV PATH /opt/node_modules/.bin:$PATH

RUN chown -R node:node /opt/app
USER node
EXPOSE 3000
CMD ["npm", "run", "start"]
```

2. See error

```
error: VipsOperation: class "heifsave_buffer" not found
Error: VipsOperation: class "heifsave_buffer" not found

throw er; // Unhandled 'error' event
```

issue.title: VipsOperation: class "heifsave_buffer" not found
issue.body:
## Bug report

**Describe the bug**
Similar to the threads indicated below. I'm receiving `VipsOperation: class "heifsave_buffer" not found` on Digital Ocean App Platform when trying to run Sharp on via Strapi CMS. Specifcally when converting to `Avif` and `WebP`.

I'm not sure if this is a host issue, or if there is something I can change within the Dockerfile for it to work.

- https://github.com/libvips/libvips/discussions/2340
- https://github.com/lovell/sharp/issues/2783

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Use Dockerfile

```
# Build
FROM node:18-alpine as build

ARG DATABASE_URL

ENV NODE_ENV=production
ENV DATABASE_URL=${DATABASE_URL}

WORKDIR /opt/
COPY package*.json ./
RUN apk add --no-cache build-base gcc autoconf automake zlib-dev libpng-dev vips-dev > /dev/null 2>&1
RUN npm install --omit=dev
ENV PATH /opt/node_modules/.bin:$PATH
WORKDIR /opt/app
COPY . .

RUN npm run build

# Run
FROM node:18-alpine as production
RUN apk add --no-cache vips-dev
ENV NODE_ENV=production

WORKDIR /opt/
COPY --from=build /opt/node_modules ./node_modules
WORKDIR /opt/app
COPY --from=build /opt/app ./
ENV PATH /opt/node_modules/.bin:$PATH

RUN chown -R node:node /opt/app
USER node
EXPOSE 3000
CMD ["npm", "run", "start"]
```

2. See error

```
error: VipsOperation: class "heifsave_buffer" not found
Error: VipsOperation: class "heifsave_buffer" not found
node:events:495
throw er; // Unhandled 'error' event
```

**Environment**
(please complete the following information)
 - OS: Node 18 Alpine

issue.title: Wrong dimensions for png with orientation via xmp metadata
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
For png images with orientations >4 the Xsize and Ysize properties return the original dimensions with any metadata rotation applied. Executing `vips_autorot` does apply the correct rotation though and the orientation can also be correctly read from the metadata.
I haven't tested if this bug also occurs for pngs with orientation metadata in different formats.

**Expected behavior**
Orientation via metadata should also be applied to the dimensions for png images like it is done automatically for jpeg images.

**Environment**
Debian Bookworm running a custom build of libvips v8.14.5. All dependencies are installed from the default debian repsoitories via aptitude.
```
    meson setup build --prefix /build/libs/ --default-library static \
        -Dcplusplus=false \
        -Dmodules=disabled \
        -Dintrospection=false \
        -Dpng=enabled \
        -Djpeg=enabled \
        -Dwebp=enabled \
        -Dheif=enabled \
        -Dexif=enabled \
        -Dimagequant=enabled \
        -Dlcms=enabled
```

comment.body:
Hi @Lumaraf,

libvips doesn't apply orientation on load (it would kill performance). Instead, it keeps the file layout the same and carries the orientation tag through as metadata. It doesn't rotate JPEGs upright either, unless you set the `autorotate` option. `vipsthumbnail` will autorotate, but only as part of the final save operation, not as part of load.

I wonder if you are using `eog` to test the output? It has a bug whereby it will autorotate JPEGs, but won't autorotate PNGs (confusingly).

issue.title: Wrong dimensions for png with orientation via xmp metadata
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
For png images with orientations >4 the Xsize and Ysize properties return the original dimensions with any metadata rotation applied. Executing `vips_autorot` does apply the correct rotation though and the orientation can also be correctly read from the metadata.
I haven't tested if this bug also occurs for pngs with orientation metadata in different formats.

**Expected behavior**
Orientation via metadata should also be applied to the dimensions for png images like it is done automatically for jpeg images.

**Environment**
Debian Bookworm running a custom build of libvips v8.14.5. All dependencies are installed from the default debian repsoitories via aptitude.
```
    meson setup build --prefix /build/libs/ --default-library static \
        -Dcplusplus=false \
        -Dmodules=disabled \
        -Dintrospection=false \
        -Dpng=enabled \
        -Djpeg=enabled \
        -Dwebp=enabled \
        -Dheif=enabled \
        -Dexif=enabled \
        -Dimagequant=enabled \
        -Dlcms=enabled
```

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -109,37 +100,14 @@ magick_sniff(const unsigned char *bytes, size_t length)
 		memcmp(bytes + 4, "ftyp", 4) != 0)
 		return "TGA";
 
-	guint32 ifd_offset = 0;
-
-	/* Big-endian TIFF header
+	/* Try to search the internal magic list for a match.
 	 */
-	if (length >= 8 &&
-		bytes[0] == 'M' &&
-		bytes[1] == 'M' &&
-		bytes[2] == 0 &&
-		bytes[3] == 42)
-		ifd_offset = ((guint32) bytes[4] << 24) |
-			((guint32) bytes[5] << 16) |
-			((guint32) bytes[6] << 8) |
-			bytes[7];
-
-	/* Little-endian TIFF header
-	 */
-	if (length >= 8 &&
-		bytes[0] == 'I' &&
-		bytes[1] == 'I' &&
-		bytes[2] == 42 &&
-		bytes[3] == 0)
-		ifd_offset = ((guint32) bytes[7] << 24) |
-			((guint32) bytes[6] << 16) |
-			((guint32) bytes[5] << 8) |
-			bytes[4];
-
-	if (length >= 10 &&
-		ifd_offset >= 6 &&
-		bytes[8] == 'C' &&
-		bytes[9] == 'R')
-		return "CR2";
+	ExceptionInfo *exception = magick_acquire_exception();
+	const MagicInfo *magic_info = GetMagicInfo(bytes, length, exception);
comment.body: ... `GetImageMagick()` would only work for formats that define the `->magick` function (see e.g. the JPEG case [here](https://github.com/ImageMagick/ImageMagick/blob/4d18167db34ea2fd199acd99420d61192d708f06/coders/jpeg.c#L1773)). The various DNG/RAW formats doesn't use this, so you'll still need to use `GetMagicInfo()`.

pull_request.title: magick: prefer use of `GetMagicInfo()`
pull_request.body:
This makes our magick sniffer aware of the various magic signatures defined with the `MagickCoderHeader` macro in ImageMagick.

See for context #3734, targets the 8.15 branch.

repo.name: libvips
repo.description: A fast image processing library with low memory needs.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -109,37 +100,14 @@ magick_sniff(const unsigned char *bytes, size_t length)
 		memcmp(bytes + 4, "ftyp", 4) != 0)
 		return "TGA";
 
-	guint32 ifd_offset = 0;
-
-	/* Big-endian TIFF header
+	/* Try to search the internal magic list for a match.
 	 */
-	if (length >= 8 &&
-		bytes[0] == 'M' &&
-		bytes[1] == 'M' &&
-		bytes[2] == 0 &&
-		bytes[3] == 42)
-		ifd_offset = ((guint32) bytes[4] << 24) |
-			((guint32) bytes[5] << 16) |
-			((guint32) bytes[6] << 8) |
-			bytes[7];
-
-	/* Little-endian TIFF header
-	 */
-	if (length >= 8 &&
-		bytes[0] == 'I' &&
-		bytes[1] == 'I' &&
-		bytes[2] == 42 &&
-		bytes[3] == 0)
-		ifd_offset = ((guint32) bytes[7] << 24) |
-			((guint32) bytes[6] << 16) |
-			((guint32) bytes[5] << 8) |
-			bytes[4];
-
-	if (length >= 10 &&
-		ifd_offset >= 6 &&
-		bytes[8] == 'C' &&
-		bytes[9] == 'R')
-		return "CR2";
+	ExceptionInfo *exception = magick_acquire_exception();
+	const MagicInfo *magic_info = GetMagicInfo(bytes, length, exception);
comment.body:
Good point, I excluded this for GraphicsMagick with commit bc31f1b536b5794b86c25030d0fff2154a3f4997.

We already use `GetImageMagick()` here:
https://github.com/libvips/libvips/blob/df8b8e247ed410138fcacec2f43f0c5c16aecc37/libvips/foreign/magick.c#L663-L666

pull_request.body:
This makes our magick sniffer aware of the various magic signatures defined with the `MagickCoderHeader` macro in ImageMagick.

See for context #3734, targets the 8.15 branch.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -109,37 +100,14 @@ magick_sniff(const unsigned char *bytes, size_t length)
 		memcmp(bytes + 4, "ftyp", 4) != 0)
 		return "TGA";
 
-	guint32 ifd_offset = 0;
-
-	/* Big-endian TIFF header
+	/* Try to search the internal magic list for a match.
 	 */
-	if (length >= 8 &&
-		bytes[0] == 'M' &&
-		bytes[1] == 'M' &&
-		bytes[2] == 0 &&
-		bytes[3] == 42)
-		ifd_offset = ((guint32) bytes[4] << 24) |
-			((guint32) bytes[5] << 16) |
-			((guint32) bytes[6] << 8) |
-			bytes[7];
-
-	/* Little-endian TIFF header
-	 */
-	if (length >= 8 &&
-		bytes[0] == 'I' &&
-		bytes[1] == 'I' &&
-		bytes[2] == 42 &&
-		bytes[3] == 0)
-		ifd_offset = ((guint32) bytes[7] << 24) |
-			((guint32) bytes[6] << 16) |
-			((guint32) bytes[5] << 8) |
-			bytes[4];
-
-	if (length >= 10 &&
-		ifd_offset >= 6 &&
-		bytes[8] == 'C' &&
-		bytes[9] == 'R')
-		return "CR2";
+	ExceptionInfo *exception = magick_acquire_exception();
+	const MagicInfo *magic_info = GetMagicInfo(bytes, length, exception);
comment.body:
Ah! They have:

```C
MagickExport const char *
GetImageMagick(const unsigned char *magick,const size_t length)
```

To find the format name from a string, then use `GetMagickInfo()` to get the `MagickInfo` for that format.

 		memcmp(bytes + 4, "ftyp", 4) != 0)

-			((guint32) bytes[6] << 16) |

comment.body:
I don't think this will work with graphicsmagick -- they have:

```C
MagickExport const MagickInfo *
GetMagickInfo(const char *name,ExceptionInfo *exception)
```

@@ -88,14 +87,6 @@ magick_sniff(const unsigned char *bytes, size_t length)
 		(bytes[4] != 0 || bytes[5] != 0))
 		return "ICO";
 
-	if (length >= 5 &&
-		bytes[0] == 0 &&
-		bytes[1] == 1 &&
-		bytes[2] == 0 &&
-		bytes[3] == 0 &&
-		bytes[4] == 0)
-		return "TTF";
comment.body:
This was removed as it would be covered by:
https://github.com/ImageMagick/ImageMagick/blob/9b109732da21e1604ec28d32926c176bffb9d3e2/coders/ttf.h#L20

pull_request.title: magick: prefer use of `GetMagicInfo()`
pull_request.body:
This makes our magick sniffer aware of the various magic signatures defined with the `MagickCoderHeader` macro in ImageMagick.

See for context #3734, targets the 8.15 branch.

repo.name: libvips
repo.description: A fast image processing library with low memory needs.

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1
